subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... A practical shorthand would be that. ... Not all dialects have just 40 phonemes. Some have more, some less. But it s OK. ... I m not arguing otherwise. ...
messageBody:
At 19:02 -0400 2007-10-30, Paul Tremblay wrote:

>My impression was that it was meant to be a bit more than that--a better
>way to write English.

A practical shorthand would be that.

>But even if it is a practical shorthand, it is a shorthand based on the
>40 sounds of the English language.

Not all dialects have just 40 phonemes. Some have more, some less. But it's OK.

>That was how it was devised, right? These 40
>sounds can be mapped to the IPA. Using the IPA
>is a very precise way to describe the sounds.
>Saying that "Awl" (or "Awe") is pronounced like
>"haul" is very imprecise since people pronounce
>"haul" differently.

I'm not arguing otherwise.

>As I said, an alphabet either has to represent words (as English has
>come to do with its standardized, non phonetical spelling), or it has to
>represent sounds. If it represents neither, then it is completely
>meaningless and cannot be used to communicate with other people. If it
>represents neither, then theoritically I can spell "ball" with
>"Pipe-Eight-Mime."

You could try to use QS as an IPA for whatever
English dialect. Or you could use it as a
standardized script. I don't use QS. I don't know
what people in the UK who have [bQT] for <bath>
do and what people who have [bæT] do.

>I cannot see any good argument against a mapping of QS to IPA.

I didn't say don't.


--
Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com
